data.text: What Luxury Items for Long-Distance Bike Touring?

Hi there folks. I’m sussing out my kit for summer riding and was wondering, what luxury’s some people take regardless of the hit taken in space and weight? I’m contemplating additional footwear, camp seats, and certain tools…I’ve been shocked at what tools some will take. Wrenches and vice grips.
riding and touring how long distance? In a tour over 300 miles I will bring certain things instead of others. also will you stop in b&b or? that I will change what I would bring. Did this help?
data.author: Qoyllur Chiran Robertson

data.text: He mentioned camp seats which suggests that he is camping.
data.author: Christine Roche

data.text: Camping and motel/b+b/hostel. Trip across Canada.

data.text: whit this information I would want to know what bike you are going to ride and see a photo. You could modify the post and add it? To me it seems a easy ride because you can stop to safe space .

data.author: Christine Roche

data.text: Definitely had some great input! A chair seems to be a must. They’re so dam heavy though. I’m starting to think about using my trailer in different ways. One response here about using a trailer as a table sparked that idea.
data.author: David Kendall

data.text: I'm waiting for a foldable camp chair from kickstarter to take on tours. Some people bring them to chill during breaks and end of the day.
data.author: Adrian Cheung

data.text: seat is a winner, so nice at the end of the day, flip flop very nice too and a folding sink, bottle opener is an absolute must 😀; I'm assuming you camp. It's always a choice between weight and comfort. Tools are not a luxury, they're a necessity, for me anyway, you got to ask yourself is it likely to break, how hard to fix on the side of the road, how far from the nearest bike shop (e.g.in France in August most shops are closed so finding repair is near impossible) etc.
data.author: Remi Branly

data.text: Obviously I agree that tools are a necessity, however some people seem to carry a whole workshop! And others little more than a multi-tool! Finding the right balance is the issue.
data.author: Huw Mundy

data.text: Thermarest chair kit sometimes and a pair of sandals often.
data.author: Christine Roche

data.text: Yes, this tool debacle stumps me. MY plan is multi tool w chain riveter, extra chain riveter in head tube, small pedal wrench(15mm), full set of Allen keys, micro cassette tool(hyper cracker? I think), mini roll of duct tape, gerber multi. I think that’s it but vice grips sound like a good idea too. Anything I’m missing?
data.author: David Kendall

data.text: zip tie, spare cable break/gear change, chain oil, gloves.
data.author: Remi Branly

data.text: This should be your tool list: Crank bros m17 multitool (includes all the allen keys you need and a chain tool), chain pin and/or chain quick link, tire levers, patch kit, pump, spare tube, chain lube, chain rag. That's it. Maaaybe spare cables. If you are biking in Canada you don't need any of that other stuff and it is just dead weight. Duct tape is fine and could be useful I guess, but i've never actually used it for anything on tour. And if you need it, you can buy it in the next town you come to. What do you need a pedal wrench for? Are you going to carry spare pedals to swap out? Most modern flat pedals can be tightened with an allen key through the back of the crank. Why carry a micro cassette tool? Cassettes are something that wear out over time, they don't break suddenly. A fresh cassette should last you all the way across Canada and beyond. If you do need a new cassette you are going to need to go to a bike shop to buy one anyway and they will have a cassette tool you can use. I have absolutely no clue what one would use vice grips for? I've never used vice grips on by bicycle even when doing home maintenance. Bring what tools you can reasonably expect to use and leave the rest at home.
data.author: Kris Bjornson

data.text: Chris Pedal wrench for putting on and maybe off after flight(boxed bike). Good point though. Pretty sure my pedals have the Allen key option although I’ve found getting sufficient torque isn’t easy. Cassette tool for if a spoke breaks drive side, which I’ve had and almost ruined a trip in the past. I feel vice grips can be used for a multitude of things, bike related and non bike related. You’re right, as far as bike mechanics go, they shouldn’t even be in the shop. Some thing is majorly wrong if you feel the need to use them. Either what you’re working on or yourself. Lol. Appreciate your feedback!
data.author: David Kendall

data.text: I take a Bushbox XL wood burning stove and also a gas stove (MSR pocketrocket), I absolutely don't need both, but the Bushbox makes every camp such an enjoyable experience that it's worth it. Flame grilled steaks and a controlled camp fire with zero trace the next day. And the gas stove earns it's place as it's so much less faff to make my morning coffee and is useful in the evenings for any veggies I want to go alongside whatever meat I cook on the Bushbox.
data.author: Huw Mundy

data.text: I'm taking my Italian coffee maker and ground coffee

data.text: after years of using a press, I switched to a folding pour-over maker, I find much less bulky to carry
data.author: Dennis Peterson

data.text: I always carry a chair, in my tool kit a very small vice grip. Look around you will be surprised how small they can get. A small little bag or extra bike and fender bolts and nuts. I carry everything except the kitchen sink. Best to go to backpacking utube videos. Great ideas on light weight compact equipment. I like a big tent. Even traveling alone. I have a kelty grand masa 4 person tent. Ya right 4 person!!!! It is not that much heavier than the light 2 person tents.
data.author: Bob Kirby

data.text: Nothing wrong with a 4 man tent. Never know when you get stuck in the rain and want to play a few rounds of snooker, right? 😉 Honestly, I'd never thought of it that way...doesn't weigh much more 👍
data.author: Adrian Cheung

data.text: I was stuck with my wife for three days. The tail end of a hurricane was there. I wasn't sure who was going to come out alive.

data.author: Bob Kirby

data.text: what have you used a vice grip for?
data.author: Kris Bjornson

data.text: some nuts become striped if stubborn and you can grab on and get it out. Sometimes there is an a standard size thrown on the bike and you only have metric tools. Also i have used it to clamp on the rear derailleur cable that broke . It enabled me to adjust it to one of the easy gears in rear so it became a three speed with 3 by front chain rings. I have used to straighten a bent spoke untill I could replace one. Fixing other camping gear. Don't leave home without one.
data.author: Bob Kirby

data.text: have you used it to defend yourself against a bear?
data.author: Deling Ren

data.text: I have also used the small vice grip when I receive a sizable cut on the sidewall of a tire. I ruffed up the inside, added a lot of glue , waited to get tacky. Then used vise grip to hold it tight against the spot. Other wise I would be walking many miles. If the year or if puncture is smaller you can wrap a Dollar around the tube at that spot. . For those riders that never experienced this type of cut. You will repair tube and five miles or less it will fail. Also on the inside of the tire. Take your roughing patch for tube repair and clean the burrs . As far as bears in the previous comment. Racoons are the biggest pest. I don't use a Bear jar and use a waterproof dry bag. Just get some. Brut men's cologne or Old Spice. A couple of squits and I have left under my fly and never had the problem. In a heavy bear area spray the bag a couple of sprays and hang by cord. Even squirrels will stay away during the daytime. They're not out at night. Always hang when in bear country especially in spring or on heavy traveled trails that the bears have been successful on raiding bikers bags. A note by using this dry bag in you panniers bags they will not have a good smell. Ok done.
data.author: Bob Kirby

data.text: what does it look like opened? Thanks

data.text: used for removing the wheels when I need to replace the inner tube/ tighten the wheel. Quick release couplings make it easy for someone to steal your wheel if not secured.
data.author: Michael Woolaghan

data.text: My tea blend
data.author: Andrew Hill

data.text: I carry a hammock chair. I will shove it down into my chum bag whenever I go cross-country riding so I have a comfortable spot to sit in the woods. I can't with a hammock and a tarp so it also doubles as a gear sling to let me pike stuff up or work on a raised surface underneath my tarp out of bad weather. One of those buys that has been shockingly amazing with how satisfied I am with it when I thought it was a waste of money at first.
data.author: Robert Crow

data.text: Folding bipod for hammock, in case I need a 2nd upright to hang from.

data.text: I pack a Luci light, it takes up little space in the bag and is nice to have an area light at night instead of always needed a flash light. During the day have to charge.
